conclusion: Square region abcd with side length 2L, uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the plane, electric field between parallel plates MN and PQ, MN is on the left half of side ad, plates have length L and are separated by distance L, particle with mass m and charge q enters at point S
The particle initially moves in a straight line through the electric field region, then travels through the magnetic field only, and must just reach side cd without exiting
When the particle is between the plates MN and PQ, it experiences electric force F₁ = qE and magnetic force F₂ = qvB (perpendicular to velocity)
After exiting the electric field region, only the magnetic force acts on the particle, causing it to move in a circular path
For a negatively charged particle moving in a magnetic field directed into the page, the circular motion will be clockwise
The radius of the circular path is r = mv/|q|B
For the particle to just reach side cd without exiting, it must travel exactly 2L vertically from its position after leaving the electric field
The condition for the particle to just reach side cd is that it must travel a half-circle with radius r, where r = 2L
The equation for the radius is mv'/|q|B = 2L
The particle's motion between the plates needs to be analyzed to relate v' to the initial velocity v₀ at point S
Within the electric field region, the particle experiences both electric and magnetic forces, and the electric field accelerates the particle while the magnetic field causes a deflection

Since the particle moves along the central line SO and is stated to move in a straight line through the electric field region, the electric field is adjusted precisely to counteract the magnetic deflection for this initial velocity
For a particle to move in a straight line while experiencing both electric and magnetic fields, qE = qv₀B
The equation E = v₀B implies the particle's velocity remains constant while in the electric field region, so v' = v₀
From the earlier condition mv'/|q|B = 2L and since v' = v₀, mv₀/|q|B = 2L
The magnitude of the velocity of the particle when it is shot into point S is v₀ = 2L|q|B/m
